Federal judge: Most abortion procedures can continue in Alabama during coronavirus pandemicBrian Lyman
 
| Montgomery AdvertiserA federal judge Sunday night ruled that abortions in Alabama can proceed during the coronavirus outbreak, despite conflicting interpretations from state officials. In a 56-page opinion, U.S. District Judge Myron Thompson blocked any attempt to punish abortion providers who use “reasonable medical judgment” for the procedure. Thompson, who issued a preliminary injunction against prosecutions of abortion providers under emergency health orders, wrote that state officials had failed to clarify whether a March order limiting elective and unnecessary medical procedures amid the COVID-19 outbreak would ban abortion proceedings. “For at least some women, a mandatory postponement until April 30 would operate as a prohibition of abortion, entirely nullifying their right to terminate their pregnancies, or would impose a substantial burden on their ability to access an abortion,” Thompson wrote. Attorneys for the state’s abortion clinics hailed Thompson’s ruling. “This decision ensures that Alabamians can continue to access the abortions they need to protect their health during this crisis,” Alexa Kolbi-Molinas, senior staff attorney at the ACLU Reproductive Freedom Project, which represented the clinics, said in a statement. “Preventing someone from getting an abortion doesn’t do anything to stop the COVID-19 virus, it just takes the decision whether to have a child out of their hands.”A message seeking comment was left with Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall’s office on Monday morning.The Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) on March 20 limited elective medical procedures. The goal was to give health care facilities space and supplies needed to treat coronavirus cases. ADPH at first signaled the order did not apply to abortions, the vast majority of which take place outside hospitals. But a week later, an amended order banned procedures not necessary to treat an “emergency medical condition.” Attorneys for the state’s three abortion clinics wrote that Marshall — who supported an attempt by Texas to stop abortions in that state during the outbreak — failed to provide clear guidance on whether they could face prosecution under the order. The clinics said the uncertainty led patients to cancel of abortion procedures. Attorneys for the state argued the state of emergency declared by Gov. Ivey in March made the ban proper. Thompson issued a temporary restraining order against criminal punishment of abortion providers on March 30. In his Sunday opinion, the judge described a hokey-pokey dance by state officials in applying the order to abortion clinics. Thompson wrote that State Health Officer Scott Harris signaled in a declaration filed on April 1 that he would defer to the judgment of doctors considering “his or her patient’s individual circumstances.” The judge wrote that the state appeared to confirm this position at an April 3 hearing, and suggested providers would be able to determine if abortion met one of the exceptions in the emergency order. But on April 5, Thompson wrote, state attorneys wrote that a provider’s judgment “is not conclusive proof” that an abortion procedure met the exceptions and that “the risk to a patient’s health be sufficiently serious” to allow an abortion to take place. “These medical restrictions are susceptible to multiple readings,” Thompson wrote. “Over the course of this litigation, the defendants themselves have put forth several divergent interpretations of the medical restrictions, each with dramatically different implications for the plaintiffs.”The judge rejected arguments that allowing abortions to continue to tax medical resources. Thompson noted the low rate of hospitalizations from abortions and wrote that the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) in abortion procedures is low. Thompson also rejected the state’s emergency powers arguments. “A fundamental right is at stake; that right, for some women, is subject to a possible permanent denial, not a mere delay or temporary denial; and, based on the Supreme Court’s clear holdings on the right to an abortion, the State’s asserted interests, even when viewed with a tremendous degree of deference, cannot support the accompanying deprivation of a Fourteenth Amendment right,” he wrote. Under Alabama law, a woman seeking an abortion must receive counseling aimed at discouraging the procedure and wait 48 hours. The woman must also go through an ultrasound and have the option of viewing it. Contact Montgomery Advertiser reporter Brian Lyman at 334-240-0185 or blyman@gannett.com.
